newsitem.title: MOZAMBIQUE: Mozambique president end of landmine production.
newsitem.headline: Mozambique president end of landmine production.

text.p: President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique called on Tuesday for an end to landmine production when he opened an international conference on the issue.

More than 300 activists from non-governmental organisations all over the world are attending the meeting in Maputo, which aims at building support for an international treaty banning landmines to be signed in Ottawa in December.
"We appeal to the producing countries to stop the manufacture, transport, sale and use of mines," said Chissano.
The conference is co-hosted by the International Campaign to Ban Landmines and an independent Mozambican association with the same aim.
"We support this movement with all our vigour and look forward to the total eradication of mines from the planet," said Chissano.
Conference organisers said there were still about one million uncleared landmines in Mozambique -- relics from wars between 1964 and 1992 -- which are still maiming and killing people.
The Mozambican campaigners against landmines said they had collected more than 100,000 signatures on a letter to Chissano calling for a ban.
Some delegates told Reuters they were disappointed that Chissano had not pledged to sign the Ottawa treaty.
Others noted that under Mozambican law his decision would have to be ratified by parliament. Chissano's Frelimo party has a majority in parliament, but ratification is not guaranteed.
One influential Frelimo deputy, Sergio Vieira, recently defended the use of landmines in some circumstances in his weekly column in the Maputo newspaper Domingo.
Graca Machel, widow of Chissano's predecessor Samora Machel, supports Chissano politically and is a strong advocate of the treaty banning landmines.

Graca, who has a romantic relationship with mine-banning proponent South African President Nelson Mandela, is chairing the Maputo conference and called for the southern African region to be mine-free by the year 2000.
